content: I was drafted in June 1972 and am trying to remember the requirements for the final PT test. Anyone remember what the time maximum time was for 100 points in the run and how long the run was?
reply: I was drafted in June 1972 and am trying to remember the requirements for the final PT test. Anyone remember what the time maximum time was for 100 points in the run and how long the run was?

content: Mar-Apr 1970 Ft. Knox, Ky It was 1 and 1/2 miles. I think you had to do it 7 mins or less to get 100...but that was in fatigues, combat boots, pistol belt and canteen. Run, dodge and jump - 30 seconds = 100 72 overhead ladder bars in 60 second = 100 130 yard man carry 1 Min 30 Sec = 100 30 yard low crawl = 60 second = 100 Total = 500 I think that's what we did. I max everything but the run - about 7 Min 30 sec for 60 Total 460 points... Wandering and Wondering
reply: Mar-Apr 1970 Ft. Knox, Ky It was 1 and 1/2 miles. I think you had to do it 7 mins or less to get 100...but that was in fatigues, combat boots, pistol belt and canteen. Run, dodge and jump - 30 seconds = 100 72 overhead ladder bars in 60 second = 100 130 yard man carry 1 Min 30 Sec = 100 30 yard low crawl = 60 second = 100 Total = 500 I think that's what we did. content: quote: Originally posted by greywolfghost: Mar-Apr 1970 Ft. Knox, Ky It was 1 and 1/2 miles. I think you had to do it 7 mins or less to get 100...but that was in fatigues, combat boots, pistol belt and canteen. Run, dodge and jump - 30 seconds = 100 72 overhead ladder bars in 60 second = 100 130 yard man carry 1 Min 30 Sec = 100 30 yard low crawl = 60 second = 100 Total = 500 I think that's what we did. I max everything but the run - about 7 Min 30 sec for 60 Total 460 points... I recall the minimum score being 300, regardless of individual event scores. You could bolo one event and make it up on another, unlike today's PT test.
quote: Originally posted by greywolfghost: Mar-Apr 1970 Ft. Knox, Ky It was 1 and 1/2 miles. I think you had to do it 7 mins or less to get 100...but that was in fatigues, combat boots, pistol belt and canteen. Run, dodge and jump - 30 seconds = 100 72 overhead ladder bars in 60 second = 100 130 yard man carry 1 Min 30 Sec = 100 30 yard low crawl = 60 second = 100 Total = 500 I think that's what we did. I max everything but the run - about 7 Min 30 sec for 60 Total 460 points...
reply: I recall the minimum score being 300, regardless of individual event scores. You could bolo one event and make it up on another, unlike today's PT test.

content: Seems to me ya had to at least score in every event. Most of the recycles bolo'd the overhead ladders, cuz they were too big and heavy to even get one rung. In fact, I think ya had to make it to the end at least once to start scoring (12 rungs). We had to do 12 rungs before every meal in garrison, because the ladders were right outside the chow hall door. After the first week, everybody had bad blisters on their hands. I had rancher/weight lifter hands, but it tore the callouses right out doing so many. And I had separated a shoulder playing football the year before - hurt like hell!!... But I had enlisted and was Plt Guide - so I sucked it up, gritted teeth and just did the damned thing every time - bloody hands or not - -F#$!K IT!! Wandering and Wondering

content: I don't remember a draft in June of 72?
reply: I don't remember a draft in June of 72?

content: quote: Originally posted by mainedawg: I don't remember a draft in June of 72? There was a draft in effect via the lottery through 1973. It's not that there is no God or that He isn't listening. You're probably just asking the wrong questions.
quote: Originally posted by mainedawg: I don't remember a draft in June of 72?
reply: There was a draft in effect via the lottery through 1973. It's not that there is no God or that He isn't listening. You're probably just asking the wrong questions.

content: I was drafted just before they stopped it sometime before March 1972. I thought they had ended it and you just had to show up and say hi when you turned 18. I remember the start of the all vol army...VOLAR I think it was called and that started in First part, early 1972.
reply: I was drafted just before they stopped it sometime before March 1972. I thought they had ended it and you just had to show up and say hi when you turned 18. I remember the start of the all vol army...VOLAR I think it was called and that started in First part, early 1972.

content: quote: Originally posted by mainedawg: I was drafted just before they stopped it sometime before March 1972. I thought they had ended it and you just had to show up and say hi when you turned 18. I remember the start of the all vol army...VOLAR I think it was called and that started in First part, early 1972. The draft lottery ended 01 July, 1973, with 646 inductees for that calender period - 1972 had 49,514 inductees. The All Volunteer Army (Project VOLAR, otherwise known as MVA (Modern Volunteer Army)) began 01 July 1973 - not 1972. While very limited in who they picked, the Army still drafted men until then, despite the 1968 demands of Nixon and the 1970 beginnings of the Gates Commission. "The last man was drafted in December 1972 and reported for training in June 1973." "http://www.shsu.edu/~his_ncp/VolArm.html" It's not that there is no God or that He isn't listening. You're probably just asking the wrong questions.
quote: Originally posted by mainedawg: I was drafted just before they stopped it sometime before March 1972. I thought they had ended it and you just had to show up and say hi when you turned 18. I remember the start of the all vol army...VOLAR I think it was called and that started in First part, early 1972.
reply: The draft lottery ended 01 July, 1973, with 646 inductees for that calender period - 1972 had 49,514 inductees. The All Volunteer Army (Project VOLAR, otherwise known as MVA (Modern Volunteer Army)) began 01 July 1973 - not 1972. While very limited in who they picked, the Army still drafted men until then, despite the 1968 demands of Nixon and the 1970 beginnings of the Gates Commission. "The last man was drafted in December 1972 and reported for training in June 1973." "http://www.shsu.edu/~his_ncp/VolArm.html" It's not that there is no God or that He isn't listening. You're probably just asking the wrong questions.

content: quote: Originally posted by mainedawg: I don't remember a draft in June of 72? End of Vietnam draft =http://www.historyplace.com/unitedstates/vietnam/index-1969.html:%5Dhttp://www.historyplace.com/unitedstates/vietnam/index-1969.html:]http://www.historyplace.com/unitedstates/vietnam/index-...nam/index-1969.html January 27, 1973 - Secretary of Defense Melvin Laird announces the draft is ended in favor of voluntary enlistment. Wandering and Wondering

content: Dang, youse guy's is a bunch o whipper snappers, I seperated from active duty August of 1967. 1972, I was married for two years! Now I'm a crusty old fart!Have four grand kids. Oldest one is twelve. Have had 3 homes, we had an apartment for the first 3 months of marriage, moved 3 times. The last move was interstate. There is a possibility of an interstate move in the future. Keep smiling, everyone will wonder what you've been up to!

content: God and the soldier, All men adore, In time of trouble, And no more; For when war is over, And all things righted, God is neglected - The old soldier slighted. Founding Member Original DVG & Proud Member, Rupterd Duck/Derelict Veterans
reply: God and the soldier, All men adore, In time of trouble, And no more; For when war is over, And all things righted, God is neglected - The old soldier slighted. Founding Member Original DVG & Proud Member, Rupterd Duck/Derelict Veterans

content: quote: Originally posted by Bergy46: Dang, youse guy's is a bunch o whipper snappers, I seperated from active duty August of 1967. 1972, I was married for two years! Now I'm a crusty old fart!Have four grand kids. Oldest one is twelve. Have had 3 homes, we had an apartment for the first 3 months of marriage, moved 3 times. The last move was interstate. There is a possibility of an interstate move in the future. I was married with a kid by 1972, and another by Feb of 74... The first was born at Ireland Army Hospital Ft. Knox in Mar 70. I was 19, and he was gona be the "Leave something behind" baby for when I shipped to Vietnam - which didn't happen - - April 1970 at home in Utah, enroute to Vietnam - but diverted to Europe by Nixon - - Wandering and Wondering
